s.text: By sliding 25 bp window (representing average primer length) incrementally along the genome in 1-bp intervals, an average of the highest log odds scores for each position (either A, C, G or T) was calculated to generate the overall degree of conservation (conservation score) for this 25-bp region.
Finally a 25-bp window, (representative of a typical primer), was walked through the genome/PWM to identify the most conserved locations for primer design.
Figure 1shows a plot of conservation score using a 10-bp window for the whole HCV genome.
Using the PWM, the most conserved stretches were rapidly identified making possible the design of robust primers based on the criteria described in Methods.
All non-commercial softwares used in this study were written in PERL 5.0.
The approach taken, to break the HCV genome into 10 pieces according to the gene boundaries, proved to be successful.
The approach taken, to break the HCV genome into 10 pieces according to the gene boundaries, proved to be successful.
The approach taken, to break the HCV genome into 10 pieces according to the gene boundaries, proved to be successful.
Design of robust primers to maximize success with unsequenced isolates ( i.e . clinical samples), is a common challenge facing the molecular virologists.
